text:
HOST: Hello. Welcome everybody
for our webinar today, on product management
and ask us anything session

with a Anand Subramani,
and Jianna Zhang, both experienced
product executives.

Anand right now is the
VP of product at Path and JZ is the VP of
product at Web Flow.

So today's session
will be Q&A driven, so you should see a little
Q&A box in your interface.

Just type a question in
there, it's a short session, we may not get to all
the questions during it,

but keep the questions coming. And with that I
think actually we'll

just get it kicked off, so
we don't waste any more time. So Anand, we spoke
this time last year.

And I should mention there are
links to our previous webinars as well, if you want to
see what Anand and JZ have

had to say before about
product management. One question that
came up last year was, how has product management
changed with the move

to fully remote work? And you said, and I'm
paraphrasing a little bit here, a small organization has to
act like a big organization.

It's harder to run things ad
hoc when everyone is remote. So you need to
develop the processes, and deliberate communication
practices that you'd expect

in a larger organization. I love this answer because it
related to your core principle

of the product manager being
the glue in an organization, responsible for inter and
intra team communication.

So a year on is there anything
you would add to that answer? Any new insights?

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure. For a tiny bit of
context, Path is remote first, and
remote forever,

so this is a thing that we have
had to figure out as a company. Two things that
really jump out to me.

One of them is about, the
first is about asynchronous and synchronous communication.

Asynchronous communication
is talking over Slack, or it's writing emails,
or writing documents.

Synchronous usually
means in person. My lived experience with this
is, synchronous communication

is much higher bandwidth. If there's a complicated
topic, or something you need to work
through with someone,

it is so much faster and
so much more effective to quote, get in
a room with them. Whether that means a virtual, a
conference, or a physical room.

So I think two years into
remote work, one of the things I think has become even more
important for product managers,

is to know which mode to be in,
and make it really easy to be in the appropriate one.

A tactical example
what that means for us, we use Slack and Zoom as
our tools of communication.

There's a magic command
and Slack slash Zoom that automatically
starts a conference, we use that all the time. I probably used 25 times a day.

So it's making sure that you're
not forcing yourself into a six paragraph conversation
with someone,

when really what you need is
a five minute conversation. Think is a high
premium on knowing which mode you should be in.

The second one is,
this just continues to be more and more true, but
documenting things is even more

important than it ever was. And it was always
important, but I would say most companies are as
included tend to do this poorly

historically, with people
being in different time zones, and often having
never met each other.

Writing things down is more
important than it's ever been, whether that means making a
little video, recording a Zoom,

making a Loom, putting it
on YouTube, writing down. Whatever it is, archiving
and saving that information,

is more important
than it's ever been.  HOST: Thanks Anand.

JZ is there anything you
would add to a Anand answer? JIANNA ZHANG: Sure.

I do say that slash Zoom as
a shortcut command in Slack,

is probably one of the best
tips I've personally gotten, and I give my team. So if you don't know
that, write that down.

To add on this concept of really
documenting decision making, it is something that is going
to help you move a lot faster.

It might not feel like it
at the very beginning, when you're writing that document. But as your company scales,
as new people come on,

having that documentation,
whether this is my PRD, my Product
Requirements Document.

This is the meeting
notes of when we had to make a really
important decision, this is the decision we made. um having a Wiki for your
company, where all of this

can live for the product
team, for your area. All of those things
are just becoming more and more important.

HOST: That's great. And I want to remind people to
continue to submit questions in the Q&A box, we're already
getting some great ones.

But I want to stay a little
bit here on this topic, and we have a good
follow up question,

and it's related again to one
of your core principles with. So JZ you talk about
bringing the donuts, the PM's

responsibility for team morale. How have you been doing that
when everybody's remote?

What are some of the challenges
and opportunities there? JIANNA ZHANG: Yeah. I think the first
thing to stress

is that, bringing the donuts
is really just a concept. You can physically
bring in donuts,

but the concept is
how do you make sure that your team
feels appreciated, they feel cohesive?

And so even in a remote
world, you can do this. Whether that is through still
physical things like mailing

people thank you notes. I know that might feel old
school, and old fashioned, but it actually really can mean
something, in today's world

that's very digital and remote. We did something recently,
where we actually mailed people
polaroids, and had them

take pictures of their family,
of things that they loved. And then we sent them back,
we had them send the pictures

back, and then we digitized it. And so just creating
that connection. Another thing that you
can do with your team

is, bringing the donuts really
means celebrating great work, and cheering your team on.

So that can take
the form of props. So in your Slack
channel, or email,

or whatever you're using, really
celebrating those moments, shouting out people who've
done a really great job, who've

done something really difficult,
who've gone above and beyond. Those are types of things
that you can do in a world

where, bringing the donuts
is a little bit harder, when we're all physically together.

HOST: Anand is
there anything you would add to this idea
of bringing the donuts, in this remote world?

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Just one which
is, this might sound corny, but don't be afraid to
formalize the concept.

One of the things
that we've done that has worked pretty well
is, we have an explicit concept

of a rotating person
every month, who's in charge of doing something
team oriented and team related.

And they plan an event,
or totally up to them their discretion.

But we formalize a little bit. And while it might sound silly,
and might sound a little bit dumb, people walk out of those.

And like actually I
had a really good time meeting my co-workers. So the team building, and the
team bonding event of this

can also be formalized
a bit, to make sure that it is somebody's job, and
that you are actually doing it.

HOST: And Anand I want to
stay with you for a little bit

longer. So we're getting
a lot of questions now about, what are the
core skills that you need to improve on as a PM, and
what are the common mistakes?

And so I want to try and
bring these together, around the core
responsibilities of a PM,

which is knowing your customer. So you argue you've got to
really be the customer's

advocate in the organization. So could you talk a little
bit about what that means, and what are the common pitfalls
that young PMs or new PMs

make when they're trying
to know the customer. ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure. In terms of what
it means, it means

that one of the things you
are uniquely responsible for, is representing your
customer inside the building,

as you are making
products, or as you're going through some
prioritization process. In terms of the most
common way that I

see this fail, especially
for new product managers, it's doing a very large
project to know your customer,

and then assuming
that you're done. It's doing a bunch of research,
and then a year from now you're saying, well we did that
research project a year ago,

we already know our customer. This is a thing you have
to do to perpetuity, and it requires constant
refreshing this information.

So I think it's about
building systems where you are constantly
connecting with your customers all the time.

Even all the way up
to an executive level. I do three to five
customer calls every week, and will until the end of time.

Just making sure that you
have a consistent check in with your customers, not
just a one time checking

with your customers. HOST: Anand can I ask a
quick follow up on that?

Are those customer
calls the same as when you're doing focus
group work, as when you're doing customer interviews?

Or are these different level
of formality or casualness? I know this is a common,
how do you build up

that skill of learning
about your customers? So it'd be great to
talk a little bit more about the structure
of those customers.

ANAND SUBRAMANI:
It really depends. I'd say there's definitely
a few different archetypes. One archetype is an escalation.

A customer had some
frustrating experience, I've sort of put the word
out to people on our team,

that if someone has a
frustrating experience of the product, you can put
them in touch with me directly.

So there's definitely one
archetype that I had a problem, I want to talk to a very
senior person on the team,

I want to feel heard,
and I also want to know that you're taking
your problem seriously. And this is actually really
phenomenal for cutting

through stuff that gets lost
in the organization, where nobody in the organization
feels empowered to fix it.

I can talk to a
customer and say, great we're fixing
this tomorrow. That's one archetype. Let's say a second
archetype is, I

have a topic that
I'm interested in, and I want to do something
exploratory about it. At Path for example,
we're starting

to think about how we can
better support therapists. I have calls over
the next few weeks with people who are
not Path customers,

but are therapists
who have recently started their own practice. And I have a script
that I've written where, I'm going
to go in, and talk

about the topic on my mind. The last one before I kick it
over JZ is, sort of informal,

like there isn't a specific
thing you want to talk about. In here I have a script that
I usually write, and just keep running through
about, tell me

what's working well
in the product, tell me what's not working well,
tell me what you wish existed, tell me if you'd
recommend it to a friend. It's really just a basic
overview of what's going on,

and then how you use it
in your day to day life. There's a lot of day in
the life type questions, and how you make
use of it questions.

HOST: That's great and
that's really helpful. JZ is there anything
you would add, to the sort of knowing
your customer skill?

JIANNA ZHANG: Yeah. What I would say here, and I'm
going to pivot a little bit,

to some of the questions
that I do see coming in. Which are really around, how
do you transition your career?

If you're doing X role, if
you're doing operations, if you're doing
business stuff, how do you transition into the
product management role?

When you can really
understand your customer, so

whether you're working on QA,
or whether you are working

in operations, but you take
the time to deeply understand what your customer needs,
that gives you an advantage

in making that transition. Because product
management, really is about understanding
that user,

and really knowing like
what are their pain points, where they're really
struggling with. So I just wanted to
address it a little bit. I know that those are
some of the questions that

are coming in. The other piece, and I also
see people asking about, hey, I have a
business background,

I am currently in consulting,
or I went to business school. How do I make that transition? The other piece of the
product management role,

is not just
understanding your user, but it's really understanding
the business context. Is there an opportunity here?

Yes there is user
pain, and if we built something
we could capture, we can serve that user pain, but
also capture a real opportunity

in the market. And so when you lean
into both of those, the deep understanding
of the user, and that opportunity
for the business,

that's when you really provide
value as a product manager. And so that is what
you can lean into,

based on your
respective background, in order to transition to
the product management role.

HOST: That's really great. And I wanted to
follow up on that. So JZ may be sticking
with you here.

This is a question
that came in that I thought was nicely worded. Which is, if we do a little
pre-mortem on a product manager

who's just started the role, and
now they're really struggling, let's say six months
in, what is it that's

causing them to struggle? What do you typically
see as a new PM, struggling in those first
six months of their role?

JIANNA ZHANG: Yeah. I think the first thing
is a lot of times, the PM role at a given
company, is not well defined.

And that is because the PM role
can be a little bit different based on the company,
based on your product, based on your users, and
what that company needs.

And so one of the
biggest reasons why new PMs might
be struggling, is because their role definition
on what they're responsible,

is not necessarily clear. Not just to them, but also to
the organization more broadly.

And so one of the things
I'd really encourage new PMs is take the time, work
with your manager,

and really define what
success looks like. And if you do take our course,
you can really start to see,

this is what it means to really
own the product life cycle. This is what it really
means to be successful.

And so taking some
of those tips, you can actually
write down, hey, this is what success looks like
as a new PM in my first 90

days, in my first six
months, in my first year. So that's one thing. I think another thing is,
there are times actually

it's quite easy
to be on projects, where it's not clear what user
problem you're solving for.

Or you can be on a project where
even though there's user pain, there isn't a clear
business opportunity. So even if you built
something that's delightful,

it's actually not going
to have a lasting impact on the business. And so when both of those things
are not true for your project,

that is also a reason
why things can go awry, and how people can be not so
successful in their first year.

And so really just
understanding, having the tools
to understand, is that happening here
with my project, with what I'm working on?

That's another big thing
to really get right, in order to be successful.

HOST: Anand is there anything
you would add to this? What do you see as
the major struggles if you're doing a pre-mortem
for a new PM, after six months?

They're really struggling,
what's the cause? ANAND SUBRAMANI: I think this
is a manifestation of JZ's

first point, that
it also addresses some of the other comments
that have been brought up in the question submissions.

It's really easy as a new PM
to be entirely reactive instead of proactive. Boss comes to you
and says, do this,

founder of the company
come to you and says, what if we did this thing? And you spend all of your time
responding to outside requests,

and no time taking your projects
and moving your projects forward. So I think there's a bunch
of questions here about, what

are some of the skills
required, to know if you will be a successful product manager? And what are some of the
skills to start working on now?

I think one of the
absolute core skills to be successful
at this role is, being able to center
yourself on your job,

is to deliver
value to customers, and excuse me, to customers and
the business simultaneously. You do that by
making stuff, and you

need to be super proactive
about taking things from start to finish,
not just about being responsive to whatever
the organization happens

to be asking today. It's very easy for organizations
to generate a lot of chaos,

and you need to wrangle
that, but if that becomes your full
time job, you're not moving your projects forward.

HOST: Anand there's
a question that came in, that I think is a
really nice follow on to this. Which is again, another
one of the core skills

that you identify, as being able
to influence without authority. So how do you get
buy in for your role?

How do you influence
when you're getting all these requests
coming in, and you need to build some space
to proactively pursue

your projects, how do you
influence without authority? I know that's a million
dollar question, if you had an easy answer, it
would be a different world.

But what are some of the
strategies, and tactics that you use, for influencing
without authority?

ANAND SUBRAMANI:
Everyone very much develops a big part of their
own personal style on this. I think a big one that I
learned early in my career

is, you can be responsive to a
bunch of these requests coming in, without it taking
up all of your time.

So the influence
without authority piece is, sometimes learning
to gently redirect things to the right place,
or to let something

sit longer than it
should, or not get back to something right away. So that you are focusing on
the most important thing.

So I think the influence
without authority piece is all about striking this
delicate line, of getting the rest of the organization
what it needs to continue,

without having that eat up
all of your hours in the day. If anybody here is a product
manager at a larger company,

I'm guessing you spend
almost all of your hours on the day interfacing with
the rest of the organization, and it's about being defensive
to get some of that time back.

HOST: JZ, what would you add
to this idea of influencing

authority without authority? It's easy to influence
with authority. Without authority, what are some
of your tactics and strategies?

JIANNA ZHANG: Yes. So we do say this, which is,
being a PM is not a solo sport,

it is a team sport. So you are a PM, you will
have an engineering manager, or partner, or tech lead.

You will have a
design partner, you have a lot of
other stakeholders. And so a large part of the
influencing without authority,

is having strong
relationships with your team, with your partners. And knowing when it is you
need to push something forward,

versus you need to encourage
your teammate to own something, and push it forward.

And so while you don't manage
all the designers on the team, you're design manager
who's your partner does.

While you don't manage all
the engineers on your team, the engineering manager
on your team does.

So when you have
those relationships, you can influence those
particular stakeholders,

to then directly manage those
who are solid line reporting up to them, to get things done.

So I think that's a huge piece. And then I think
cross-functionally, this is across the team.

The PM team while does
feel kind of lonely, in terms of are the
PM in your area,

there isn't really another PM. You are usually part
of a PM organization. So there's another
PM, on other projects,

you have group PMs, directors,
VPs so and so forth. And so your PM team is
a really huge asset,

bringing things early
and often to the PM team, finding best practices for
that team to really gelled,

and cohesive, and synced in
their strategy, that really helps you get things done.

Because instead
of you constantly trying to get a million
stakeholders aligned, you can leverage the PMs
across the organization,

to all move in unison. And so that is a huge
piece of also creating that network effect, and
influencing across the company.

HOST: That's really interesting. And it's always
one of the things I think we all struggle with,
it's one of the hardest skills.

I want to pivot. So I do want to save
some time, because we're getting so many
of those questions around, how do I transition?

And what does it
mean to be a PM? But there is one
other question that came in, that I want to
ask you JZ, before pivoting

to that question. And that's, is
there a difference, or what is the
difference between being

a PM for a new product, and
potentially a new product in a new industry,
we got a question

there's no industry for this,
what are the benchmarks? Versus being a
product manager when you're coming into a company,
maybe the PM for an established

product. So the core question
is, is there? And what is the
difference between being a PM for a new product,
and an established product?

JIANNA ZHANG: Yeah. I'll start with first
the similarities. So as a PM regardless of
what product you're on,

you have to deeply
understand your users. Again, we're going to sound
like a broken record, and also the business opportunity.

If you don't understand
that, whether you're building something
brand new, or you're trying to add to an
existing product,

but shape it, evolve it in the
way that is most impactful, you can't do either of
those successfully,

if you don't have a
fundamental understanding of, who are you building for? What do they need? And am I going to actually
have a meaningful impact

there, such that it becomes
a business opportunity? That being said, there are
definitely some differences.

So with a new
product, the things I would really advise
PMs to really focus on

is, what is the state of
the world today, in terms of just alternatives?

Who are the competitors that
you think your audience is going to be using? If there are no
competitors, what

are the workaround
solutions that people are kind of gluing
together, that you think you can do a much better job at?

Those are the things you
really look at, when you're building something zero to one. When you're building something
that is more established,

you actually have the benefit
of having so much data. You don't have to necessarily
go outside of the company,

and try to do these
benchmarks or approximations, you can actually work
with your data team.

You can go directly and see, how
are people using these features in the past?

How do I segment my cohorts? What is working? What isn't working? What is the data, the
logging our charts really

say about what's going on here? And so that's a big
difference, that I think when you're working
on an existing product,

to really leverage and focus on. So that you can actually
make the best decisions going forward, for how to evolve it.

HOST: That's great. Anand would you add
anything to this question?

The kind of establish
product versus new. ANAND SUBRAMANI: 20 seconds,
and then I think a lot of people

are interested in
how they become a PM. So 20 seconds on this. Just expanding on what
JZ said at the beginning,

I think a huge difference
is a new product fits more into the context of
the rest of their life,

and an existing
product often fits into the context of itself. If you're a PM
working on a feature

at a huge established product,
a Google, or Microsoft, or whatever. A lot of your work will
be, how does this thing

fit into the other parts of
the product that we control? And if you are in
former category,

it's all about
fitting your product into the rest of their life. Are they going to use things at
work, or at home, for personal,

or for play? What are their
replacement solutions? What are our competitors? So the context in
which you're thinking

fits is pretty
different, and that puts a different premium on
where you spend your time.

HOST: Perfect. Thank you Anand. And JZ I want to
come back to you. So again, lots and lots
of questions about,

how do I become a PM? And you've already
addressed some of it, finding that marriage
between business,

what's good for the business,
and knowing your customer. What other advice
would you provide

in terms of making
that transition from different roles, into
the product management role?

What should people
be thinking about? JIANNA ZHANG: Yeah. I think someone
actually brought this up

in chat where they said,
it is really tricky, because one of the
best ways to get a job, is to already have the title,
and it becomes this catch-22.

So that is true. But a couple of ways
to think about this is, first if you're
at a company,

and you're really excited
to transition to a PM role at that particular
company, I think what you do is really
find that wedge

where you're adding value
to an existing team. Whether it's more on the
business side, whether it's

more on the understanding
the user side. Like I am a designer, and I
really understand the user.

Transitioning from that,
into product management. Or I'm a data
scientist, and I really understand how our
product works, but also

the intersection of how our
users are using this product. That is something
that's an asset for you,

to transition into the PM role. If you're going to do this
at a completely new company,

if you don't see
those opportunities at your existing company. One of the things that Anand
and I do advise people to do

is, sometimes when
you go smaller, there are more opportunities to
really just wear multiple hats.

When you're at a
small company, you might be doing a little
bit of operations, and you might be doing
a little bit of product,

and over time you
do more product, and officially become a PM. And so that's
another opportunity to think about,
which is, can you

find it at your
existing company? Or do you need to potentially
look at a different company, and based on the
opportunities at that company,

to make that transition?  HOST: Anand I want
to give you a second

to add anything to JZ's
answer, but I do also want to ask you about some
of the formal learning experiences, that you
and JZ have put together

around classes. So anything you would
add to JZ's response, before talking about kind
of formal ways of learning

about PM? ANAND SUBRAMANI:
Just an expansion of first point, which is,
if you're new to the product discipline, you
probably don't know

a lot about product
management, you have to bring some other asset. You need to be
super intellectually honest about the other
asset that you bring.

The most common two
assets that I see, if you will transition
to this, are either. Are one, people who know
a lot about the customer.

Most common rules here are sales
roles, customer service roles, customer support roles. People who spend all day
talking to the customer,

and know a lot
about the customer. I mean I know about
product management, but that's the trade. You know a ton
about the customer,

somebody else will teach you
about product management. The other one is on
the business side. Some of this comes out
of sales, some of it

comes out of business school,
some of it out of consulting. It's knowing a ton about
both how this business works,

and how business
works in general. And again the trade
is, I bring that skill, and you teach me
product management.

HOST: Well, that's
[LAUGHS] a perfect segue. So I guess my
follow up question, and we're running
out of time, I know

you both have to
go back to work, and everyone else probably
on this call does too. You and JZ have put together
both a asynchronous course,

a self-paced course
on product management. You're also teaching a
graduate level course at Stanford, that is
open to enrollment,

and if people are
interested, there there's a link there in
the interface, you can click on that,
you can enroll.

Can you talk about
those two courses, and what the different
audiences are? And while you're doing
that, I'm actually

going to launch a poll, just
to learn a little bit more about our audience, and what
kind of learning experiences they're interested in, which can
help us refine what we offer.

ANAND SUBRAMANI: Sure. I'd say the biggest difference
between the two of them, is the self-paced
online class, is sort of

like the video
analog of a textbook. You're doing it by
yourself, you're doing it at your own
pace, the time commitment

is relatively low, it's on
the order of a dozen hours. It's whatever you put in,
is what you will get out.

But I would think of it as
sort of a it's like a textbook. The in-person graduate class
is much more expansive.

You'll work with a team which
is better representative how product managers
work in real life. You will take a real project
from start to finish,

you will go through product
reviews and design reviews. It's much longer,
so it's probably on the order of five to
15 hours a week of work.

So think of the
online class sort of the equivalent of
getting a text book, and reading a textbook,
and the other one

is more like going to school
for an entire quarter, on how to do this well.

HOST: JZ, is there anything you
would add to the differences, in those two formal
learning experiences?

JIANNA ZHANG: I mean, I
think those are really, those are the key ones. Boiling it down to
your time commitment.

How much time of your day
can you actually carve out, to really spend with this?

If you don't have a lot
of time, we definitely recommend the online version. It is self-paced,
and it will give you

a lot of the
frameworks you need, but in a digestible way,
at the pace you need.

And then the other one
is, when you're like, I want to go all in. I want a more
immersive experience, and I'd learned best by
partnering, and really trying

to do, as opposed to
reading or watching.

HOST: Great. We're running up on time. I did want to mention
there was one question. The graduate course you
enroll, and then there we

review the application, and
